AMERICAN JOURNAL
4 PUBLIC HEALTH BRIEFS
Public 0 Health reprint Validation of Self-Reported Smoking Behavior: Biochemical Analyses of Cotinine and Thiocyanate
NANCY JEAN HALEY, PHD, CARYN M. ANEL RAD. MS, AND KATHRYN A. TILTON, BS
Abstract: Hoochemical determinations of plasma and salivary colinine and thiocyanate were used to differentiate smokers from non-smokers and to follow daily smoking patterns in sittukers. Results indicate that caligine is better suited than this yahale to Jętermine smoking status in large scale epidemiologie Mudies and 10 follow alterationsan woking behavior over periods of time Salivary colanine is a reliable alternative to plasma fur validatiun ul smoking Hatus and fur fullawing changes in daily smoking putterms 14m / . Pubic Hewlik 1983, 73.1204-1201 1
Introduction
Smoking control research has generally relied upon velf. . report for information concerning smoking status, but the validity of this measure is severely limited ,Demial and manamizing the extent of cigarette smoking are commun practices among youth and announced quitters . There- fore, investigators"! recognize the need for buschemical validation of smoking behavior. There is controversy how- cvEr, concerning the most appropriate measuring devices for smoking status Salivary sampling has been suggested as an alternative to invasive venipuncture, but the relaion of salivary levels to playne levels of sigarette vifuke metabo lites remain imprecise Thiusyanate measurement bas bech used in large viale epidemiolgie studies " "
We investigated the question of whether sutinine ur theocyanate measurements should be used to separate smuk. ers from non smokers, to follow changes in daily cigarette smoke absorption aod to investigate smuker compensatiun. We also attempted to validate analysis of these components
Methods
Experiment 1
· Thirty individuals were asked to volunteer buth bloud and saliva samples The participants were 12 vinukers and 18 nonsmokers Blood was collected intu valutainers contain. ing EDTA as the anticoagulant and resulting plasma was .
frozen
Salas& was collected at the same time Participants were instructed id deposit saliva directly into a vial marked at the' one ml level Control studies un this method showed routine resuvery of more than 95 per cent of both exogenous thaxcyanate and 'H-comnine.
Participants then completed a questionnaire on smoking behavior as well as a 24-hour dietary recall. Experiment 1
Twy omukers" and two non-smokers were asked for a saliva sample each morning for two or four weeks Samples were collected directly into premarked vials and then frozen. Dietary recalls were requested from both smokers and nun- smukers
Analytical Techniques
Cotinine was quantitated by a modification of the radio- immundassay (RIA] as developed by Langone, et af " This - method uses a specific antiserum produced by injection of trans 4 casbutycutinane bound to albumin into tabounts The inter and intra assay variations are less than.b per cent. Approximately 60 samples plus standards and controls can be analyzed per day with this RIA methodology Results compare well with those obtained by GL.C.
. Hasma theocy anate was determined by an automated procedure following the method of Butts, er ul " Saliva was analy zed for thiocyanate content following suitable dilution. Samples were run in duplicate with excellent reproducibility (=1 5 per cent).
Results
Table 1 displays the mean thioxydhate and cotinine values for plasma and saliva. . No cotinine was detected in non vikers Plasma thiocyanate was increased in smokers compared to'nun smokers. reinforcing the consensus of other researchers that plasma thaocyahale levels greater than 100 JAMA can serve as utdjcators of regular smoking bebav.
Salivary analysis for cotinine showed high levels pres- ent in smokers ( 161 ou ml) with no coutmine being detected in nun sinukers Comparisons of salivary thiocyanate in theve Buups showed a difference in mean values, but a loss of resolution in the standard deviations This is better ilustraf. ed in Figures LA and 1B where individual values san he compared In both plasma and saliva, totinine analy ses sould distinguish between smokers and non-smokers with a high degree of accuracy, while thisk yanate determinations pro- vide a less clear cut answer. The ""grey area" resulted from smokers reporting 10 or less cigarettes smoked per day as well as fruin 20 per cent of the non-smoking group & otimine in plasma and saliva is lightly correlated 10 Wh while the correlation fur thiocyonate in plasma and saliva is less than
Chiucyanate levels are influenced by daily food con- sumption, but dietary recalls for the collection periods showed ho abnormal consumption of vegetables, or products known to influence the dietary background for thisyanate. .
Daily salivary analyses of cotinine and thiocyanate in nonsmokers gave the results for thiocyanate shown in Figure
From the Naylor Dans Envistute fur Disease Prevention Amencan Health

Abstract: Hoochemical determinations of plasma and salivary
colinine and thiocyanate were used to differentiate smokers from
non-smokers and to follow daily smoking patterns in sittukers.
Results indicate that caligine is better suited than this yahale to
Jętermine smoking status in large scale epidemiologie Mudies and 10
follow alterationsan woking behavior over periods of time Salivary
colanine is a reliable alternative to plasma fur validatiun ul smoking
Hatus and fur fullawing changes in daily smoking putterms 14m /
Introduction
Smoking control research has generally relied upon velf.
. report for information concerning smoking status, but the
validity of this measure is severely limited ,Demial and
manamizing the extent of cigarette smoking are commun
practices among youth and announced quitters . There-
fore, investigators"! recognize the need for buschemical
validation of smoking behavior. There is controversy how-
cvEr, concerning the most appropriate measuring devices for
smoking status Salivary sampling has been suggested as an
alternative to invasive venipuncture, but the relaion of
salivary levels to playne levels of sigarette vifuke metabo
lites remain imprecise Thiusyanate measurement bas bech
used in large viale epidemiolgie studies " "
We investigated the question of whether sutinine ur
theocyanate measurements should be used to separate smuk.
ers from non smokers, to follow changes in daily cigarette
smoke absorption aod to investigate smuker compensatiun.
We also attempted to validate analysis of these components
Methods
Experiment 1
· Thirty individuals were asked to volunteer buth bloud
and saliva samples The participants were 12 vinukers and 18
nonsmokers Blood was collected intu valutainers contain.
ing EDTA as the anticoagulant and resulting plasma was
frozen
Salas& was collected at the same time Participants were
instructed id deposit saliva directly into a vial marked at the'
one ml level Control studies un this method showed routine
resuvery of more than 95 per cent of both exogenous
thaxcyanate and 'H-comnine.
Participants then completed a questionnaire on smoking
behavior as well as a 24-hour dietary recall.
Experiment 1
Twy omukers" and two non-smokers were asked for a
saliva sample each morning for two or four weeks Samples
were collected directly into premarked vials and then frozen.
Dietary recalls were requested from both smokers and nun-
smukers
Analytical Techniques
Cotinine was quantitated by a modification of the radio-
immundassay (RIA] as developed by Langone, et af " This -
method uses a specific antiserum produced by injection of
trans 4 casbutycutinane bound to albumin into tabounts The
inter and intra assay variations are less than.b per cent.
Approximately 60 samples plus standards and controls can
be analyzed per day with this RIA methodology Results
compare well with those obtained by GL.C.
. Hasma theocy anate was determined by an automated
procedure following the method of Butts, er ul " Saliva was
analy zed for thiocyanate content following suitable dilution.
Samples were run in duplicate with excellent reproducibility
(=1 5 per cent).
Results
Table 1 displays the mean thioxydhate and cotinine
values for plasma and saliva. . No cotinine was detected in
non vikers Plasma thiocyanate was increased in smokers
compared to'nun smokers. reinforcing the consensus of
other researchers that plasma thaocyahale levels greater than
100 JAMA can serve as utdjcators of regular smoking bebav.
Salivary analysis for cotinine showed high levels pres-
ent in smokers ( 161 ou ml) with no coutmine being detected in
nun sinukers Comparisons of salivary thiocyanate in theve
Buups showed a difference in mean values, but a loss of
resolution in the standard deviations This is better ilustraf.
ed in Figures LA and 1B where individual values san he
compared In both plasma and saliva, totinine analy ses sould
distinguish between smokers and non-smokers with a high
degree of accuracy, while thisk yanate determinations pro-
vide a less clear cut answer. The ""grey area" resulted from
smokers reporting 10 or less cigarettes smoked per day as
well as fruin 20 per cent of the non-smoking group & otimine
in plasma and saliva is lightly correlated 10 Wh while the
correlation fur thiocyonate in plasma and saliva is less than
Chiucyanate levels are influenced by daily food con-
sumption, but dietary recalls for the collection periods
showed ho abnormal consumption of vegetables, or products
known to influence the dietary background for thisyanate. .
Daily salivary analyses of cotinine and thiocyanate in
nonsmokers gave the results for thiocyanate shown in Figure
